Award.AwardTitle: Cohomological and singularity invariants via Hodge modules and derived equivalences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This mathematical research project concerns algebraic geometry and related topics. Some of the problems under study in the project involve the extension of tools of algebraic geometry using algebraic structures called Hodge modules. Others involve checking invariance of various topological quantities under derived equivalences. All parts of the project will have a broad range of applications, further knowledge in the field, initiate interaction among people of different mathematical backgrounds, and produce problems suitable for research involvement of Ph.D. students.

This project studies cohomological, numerical, and singularity invariants of projective manifolds by looking at their derived categories of coherent sheaves, and by applying techniques from generic vanishing and mixed Hodge module theory. The PI would like to develop a vanishing, injectivity and extension package to be added to Saito's Kodaira-type vanishing theorem for Hodge modules, and to use this in order to attack problems on the variation of families of varieties of varieties of general type or Kodaira dimension zero. He is also interested in studying generalizations of multiplier ideals coming from the Hodge filtration on localized D-modules, and to use this for attacking a conjecture on singularities of theta divisors. Another aim is to study singularities in the minimal model program by establishing a connection between Saito's theory and the filtered de Rham complex of singular varieties. In the direction of derived categories, the main topic under study is comparison of the cohomological invariants and the geometry of varieties with equivalent bounded derived categories of coherent sheaves, a topic of interest both in mirror symmetry and in birational geometry. Continuing work on the behavior of the Picard variety and of certain Hodge numbers under derived equivalence, the PI plans to address problems like the invariance of the canonical cohomology and the invariance of cohomological support loci coming from generic vanishing theory. He is also interested in studying similar questions in the singular setting, extending some previous work in the case of varieties with quotient singularities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mihnea Popa -- Project Outcomes Report

 

The research. In work supported by this grant, the PI has focused on applying the theory of mixed Hodge modules,  a vast extension of classical Hodge theory developed by M. Saito,  to concrete problems in complex and birational geometry. He pursued the development of the theory of Hodge ideals associated to divisors on smooth varieties, in collaboration with M. Mustata. They completed this task in the case of reduced hypersurfaces, providing a generalization of certain types of multiplier ideals, and gave applications regarding the singularities of theta divisors, and of hypersurfaces in projective space or toric varieties. The PI has also been involved, together with C. Schnell, in applying the theory of Hodge modules towards the study of the variation of families smooth projective varieties of varieties, e.g. hyperbolicity questions in the sense of Viehweg, and also towards extending the full results of generic vanishing theory to the setting of compact Kaehler manifolds (the latter jointly with G. Pareschi as well).In the process, he worked on completing the vanishing and positivity package for mixed Hodge modules, by providing a generalization of the Kawamata-Viehweg vanishing theorem, as well as of the Fujita-Kawamata and Zuo-Brunebarbe semipositivity results for Hodge bundles and kernels of generalized Kodaira-Spencer maps (the latter jointly with L. Wu).The PI also continued working towards the classification of subvarieties with minimal cohomology class on principally polarized abelian varieties, and its link with generic vanishing subschemes. He was able to classify the latter in dimension up to five, in joint work with Casalaina-Martin and Schreieder, answering a conjecture made earlier jointly with Pareschi. 

 

Intellectual merit and broader impacts. Problems addressed during this award were of interest to researchers in adjacent fields, like complex analytic geometry and mirror symmetry (Hodge modules, compact Kaehler manifolds, derived categories), and led to interactions with them. The material was suitable for a number of fruitful collaborations.  It contained problems accessible to graduate students as well; for instance there is a whole range of basic questions regarding applications of Hodge modules to algebraic geometry that the PI's students have beenaddressing. The PI maintains a website with links to preprints, and course and summer school lecture notes. He recently wrote a survey for a wider audience, on the applications of mixed Hodge modules to geometric problems.Over the period covered by this NSF grant, the PI supervised four Ph.D. students (Yajnaseni Dutta, Sebastián Olano, Lei Wu, and Mingyi Zhang), one undergraduate student (Araminta Gwynne), one postdoc (Jian Xiao), and two longer term visitors at the postdoctoral level (Stefan Schreieder (Bonn) and Behrouz Taji (Freiburg)). In Fall 2015 he was a panelist and advisor for the GROW conference at Northwestern, a program for undergraduate women in mathematics. He was one of the organizers of the AMS Summer Institute in Algebraic Geometry, held in July 2015 at the University of Utah. This is a once a decade conference, which in 2015 had over 700 participants; organizational work spanned a few years. He is a co-editor of the proceedings volume. In March 2015, the PI delivered an invited address at an AMS Central Sectional meeting.  In addition, he spoke at numerous schools, conferences, colloquia and seminars, both in the US and abroad.During the academic year 2016-2017 the PI co-organized an emphasis year in Algebraic Geometry, Number Theory and Physics at Northwestern. Throughout the year there were visitors in residence, special courses and lecture series, as well as larger workshops.
